Description: Wooden coffin and lid of the lady Nesmut, decorated with polychrome figures and inscriptions. The lid carries a face-mask framed by a striped wig, and wearing a floral collar. Below is a central inscription flanked by panels containing representations of deities, including Osiris, Ra-Horakhty and the Sons of Horus. The case has a large inscription around the outside containing a request for food-oferings. The interior bears a large painted figure of the goddess Nut on the floor, with the arms rising up the sides, accompanied by additional inscriptions.
Funder name: With contribution from: British Museum Friends
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: George Sutherland-Leveson-Gower, 3rd Duke of Sutherland
Acquisition notes: Coffin was among a group given by the Egyptian Government to the Prince of Wales in 1869. This one then given to the Third Duke of Sutherland, one of the travelling companions of the Prince during his visit to Egypt in that year. Subsequently exhibited in the museum at Dunrobin castle, Sutherland, Scotland, created by the Duke in 1878.
